{{Infobox event | title = Bounty Scandal | image = File:New Orleans Saints logo.svg | image_size = 100px | caption = New Orleans Saints | venue = NFL | date = 2009–2012 | outcome = Mass suspensions, [[United States district court|federal court]] hearings and litigation | participants = [[Gregg Williams]], [[Sean Payton]], Michael Ornstein, [[Joe Vitt]], 22 to 27 Saints players }}
The '''New Orleans Saints bounty scandal''', widely dubbed "'''Bountygate''',"<ref>{{cite news|url=https://sports.yahoo.com/nfl/news?slug=ycn-11050204|title='Bountygate' Details Get Uglier by the Moment|last=Silverman|first=Steve|date=2012-03-04|accessdate=2012-03-05|publisher=[[Yahoo! Sports]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/sports/football/nfl-start-cleaning-bountygate-sean-payton-gregg-williams-role-saints-bounty-system-article-1.1032536|title=NFL needs to start cleaning up 'BountyGate' by going after Sean Payton and Gregg Williams for role in Saints' bounty system|last=Coffey|first=Wayne|date=2012-03-03|accessdate=2012-03-05|publisher=''[[New York Daily News]]''}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.startribune.com/sports/vikings/141252903.html|title=Bountygate Re: Favre|last=Souhan|first=Jim|date=2012-03-02|accessdate=2012-03-05|publisher=''[[Star Tribune]]''}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://espn.go.com/blog/new-york/jets/post/_/id/10854/did-rexs-former-team-put-out-bounties|title=Did Rex's Former Team Put Out Bounties?|last=Cimini|first=Rich|date=2012-03-04|accessdate=2012-03-05|publisher=''[[ESPN]]''}}</ref> was an incident in which members of the [[New Orleans Saints]] team of the [[National Football League]] (NFL) were found guilty of paying out bonuses, or "[[bounty (reward)|bounties]]", for injuring opposing team players. The pool was alleged to have been in operation from [[2009 New Orleans Saints season|2009]] (the year in which the Saints won [[Super Bowl XLIV]]) to [[2011 New Orleans Saints season|2011]].
League commissioner [[Roger Goodell]] responded with some of the most severe sanctions in the league's 92-year history, and among the most severe punishments for in-game misconduct in North American professional sports history. Defensive coordinator [[Gregg Williams]] was suspended indefinitely, though this would be overturned the following year. Head coach [[Sean Payton]] was suspended for the entire [[2012 NFL season|2012 season]]—the first time since [[Chuck Fairbanks]] in 1978 that a head coach had been suspended. General manager [[Mickey Loomis]] was suspended for the first eight games of the 2012 season. Assistant head coach [[Joe Vitt]] was suspended for the first six games of the 2012 season. The Saints organization was penalized with a $500,000 fine and forced to forfeit their second-round draft selections in [[2012 NFL Draft|2012]] and [[2013 NFL Draft|2013]]. In May 2012, four current and former Saints players were suspended after being named as ringleaders in the scandal, with linebacker [[Jonathan Vilma]] also being suspended for the entire 2012 season.<ref name="ESPNplayers">{{cite news|url=http://espn.go.com/nfl/story/_/id/7881761/nfl-bans-four-players-new-orleans-saints-bounty-roles|title=Jonathan Vilma banned one year|publisher=[[ESPN]]|date=2012-05-02}}</ref> However, former commissioner [[Paul Tagliabue]] overturned all sanctions against the players in December 2012 after finding that despite the players being "very much involved", the coaches and the Saints organization were primarily responsible for the scandal.<ref name=Tagliabuevacate/>
==Background== [[File:Gregg Williams at Tulane Commencement 2010.jpg|thumb|100px|right|Saints defensive coordinator [[Gregg Williams]]]] The NFL has long frowned upon bounties, or "non-contract bonuses" as it officially calls them; but an underground culture of bounties is alleged to exist, with teams, it is claimed, [[turning a blind eye]] to the practice. The league constitution specifically forbids payment of bonuses based on performances against an individual player or team, as well as bonuses for on-field misconduct; the NFL holds that such practices undermine the integrity of the game, and also would allow teams to use such payments to circumvent the [[salary cap]]. The [[collective bargaining agreement]] with the [[NFL Players Association]] also forbids this practice, as does the standard NFL player contract.<ref name=NFLStatement/> Every year, the NFL sends a memo reiterating this ban to every team before training camp opens. However, according to many former players, bounty systems of some sort have been around the NFL for decades, with the percentage of players participating non-scientifically estimated to be between 30 and 40 percent.<ref name=Freeman2>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbssports.com/nfl/story/17595418/saints-took-common-practice-of-a-bounty-system-to-new-dangerous-level|title=Saints took common practice of bounties to new, dangerous level|last=Freeman|first=Mike|publisher=[[CBSSports.com]]|date=2012-03-05|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121020180352/http://www.cbssports.com/nfl/story/17595418/saints-took-common-practice-of-a-bounty-system-to-new-dangerous-level|archivedate=2012-10-20|df=}}</ref> According to these players, such bounty programs were usually informal and often between players only, more with intent at locker-room braggadocio than systemic malice. What would draw attention to the Saints' bounty program was the alleged practice of methodically organizing such a concept at the coaches' level, with the primary intent to systematically and routinely injure opposing star players.
After the Saints defeated the [[Minnesota Vikings]] in the [[2009–10 NFL playoffs#NFC Championship: New Orleans Saints 31, Minnesota Vikings 28 (OT)|NFC Championship Game]], several Vikings players and coaches claimed that the Saints were deliberately trying to hurt Vikings quarterback [[Brett Favre]]. The Vikings were particularly angered when Saints defensive end [[Bobby McCray]] and defensive tackle [[Remi Ayodele]] knocked Favre to the ground with a high-low hit. McCray hit Favre below the knees, briefly knocking Favre out of the game with an ankle injury. No penalty was called on the play, though NFL vice president of officiating [[Mike Pereira]] said one should have been called, saying it was "the type of hit we don't want." Vikings coach [[Brad Childress]] later said that there were at least 13 instances where he felt the Saints deliberately went after Favre. Later, [[CBSSports.com]] NFL columnist Clark Judge said several Vikings assistants told him they believed McCray was acting on direct orders from Williams, with at least one being so outraged that he threatened to "punch [Williams] in the face" the next time they met.<ref name=ClarkJudge>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbssports.com/nfl/story/17546706/saints-team-officials-involved-in-bounty-program-should-pay-dearly|title=Saints, team officials involved in bounty program should pay dearly|last=Judge|first=Clark|publisher=[[CBSSports.com]]|date=2012-03-02}}</ref> Vikings owner [[Zygi Wilf]] even went as far as to complain to the league about what happened to Favre, though no action was taken at the time.<ref name=Seifert>{{cite news|url=http://espn.go.com/blog/nfcnorth/post/_/id/39041/saints-shots-at-brett-favre-were-no-secret|title=Saints' shots at Favre were no secret|last=Seifert|first=Kevin|publisher=[[ESPN]]|date=2012-03-05}}</ref> Favre took such a severe beating that Vikings punter [[Chris Kluwe]] and placekicker [[Ryan Longwell]] wondered during the game if someone had put a bounty on him.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://espn.go.com/blog/nfcnorth/post/_/id/39907/chris-kluwe-ban-jonathan-vilma-for-life|title=Chris Kluwe: Ban Jonathan Vilma for life|last=Seifert|first=Kevin|publisher=[[ESPN]]|date=2012-03-22}}</ref>
Favre's agent, Bus Cook, later said that he also felt the Saints were deliberately trying to knock Favre out of the game, and claimed that several hits on [[Arizona Cardinals]] quarterback [[Kurt Warner]] in the divisional round a week earlier crossed the line as well.<ref name=ESPNBounty>{{cite news|url=http://espn.go.com/nfl/story/_/id/7638603/new-orleans-saints-defense-had-bounty-program-nfl-says|title=NFL: Saints defense had 'bounty' fund|publisher=[[ESPN]]|date=2012-03-02}}</ref> It initially appeared that Cook's argument was strengthened by the fact that Warner was knocked out of that game with a chest injury (although he later returned), and retired two weeks later. However, Warner later said that the hit which knocked him out was legal, and had nothing to do with his decision to retire.<ref name=Warner>{{cite news|url=http://espn.go.com/blog/nfcwest/post/_/id/59989/warner-saints-hit-legal-not-career-ending|title=Warner: Saints hit legal, not career-ending|last=Bando|first=Sal|publisher=[[ESPN]]|date=2012-03-04}}</ref>
==Investigation==
[[File:Roger Goodell at Super Bowl 43.jpg|thumb|right|100px|NFL Commissioner [[Roger Goodell]]]] In the 2010 offseason, an anonymous player told NFL officials that the Saints had targeted Favre and Warner as part of a bounty program administered by Williams; the NFL's security department found the allegations credible enough to open an investigation. However, the players and team officials interviewed all denied that any bounty program existed, and the player who made the initial report subsequently recanted his allegations.<ref name=NFLStatement/><ref name=King>{{cite news|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2012/writers/peter_king/03/02/saints.bounties/index.html|title=Saints looking at severe punishment for bounty system|last=King|first=Peter|authorlink=Peter King (sportswriter)|publisher=[[Sports Illustrated]]|date=2012-03-02}}</ref>
The NFL began investigating the Saints in 2010 in response to allegations of deliberate attempts to injure players during the [[2009–10 NFL playoffs|2009–10 playoffs]], but the investigation stalled until late in the 2011 season. On March 2, 2012, the NFL announced that it had evidence that [[defensive coordinator]] [[Gregg Williams]] had created the program soon after his arrival in 2009, and alleged that "between 22 and 27 Saints players" were involved.<ref name=NFLStatement>{{cite web|url=http://www.nola.com/saints/index.ssf/2012/03/full_nfl_statement_into_bounty.html|title=Full NFL statement on bounty investigation|author=[[National Football League]]|date=2012-03-02|accessdate=2012-03-05}}</ref> Williams and the players pooled their own money to pay out performance bonuses. It also asserted that head coach [[Sean Payton]] tried to cover up the scheme, and that he and general manager [[Mickey Loomis]] failed to shut it down when ordered to do so by team owner [[Tom Benson]]. Since then, Williams has been accused of operating similar schemes during his tenure as defensive coordinator of the [[Tennessee Titans|Tennessee Oilers/Titans]] and [[Washington Redskins]] and as head coach of the [[Buffalo Bills]]; the NFL briefly investigated these allegations but elected to focus on the Saints.
==Whistleblower==
In 2012, ESPN reported that former New Orleans Saints defensive assistant Mike Cerullo contacted the NFL regarding a bounty program after the 2009 postseason. <ref name=Barr1>{{cite news|url=http://www.espn.com/espn/otl/story/_/id/8744952/mike-cerullo-former-new-orleans-saints-assistant-sends-letter-former-nfl-commissioner-paul-tagliabue|title=Mike Cerullo: I've been 'vilified'|last=Barr|first=John|publisher=[[ESPN]]|date=2012-12-03}}</ref> Cerullo was released after the 2009 postseason for poor performance and lying about personal leave according to the New Orleans Saints.<ref name=Katzenstein1>{{cite news|url=http://www.nola.com/saints/index.ssf/2017/12/sean_payton_mike_cerullo.html|title=Sean Payton: NFL hiring of bounty whistleblower Mike Cerullo 'unbelievable'|last=Katzenstein|first=Josh|publisher=[[NOLA.com]]|date=2017-12-10}}</ref> Cerullo testified that he kept track of payments and pledges made. Cerullo also states in the article, "I was angry for being let go from the Saints". In the summer of 2017, the NFL hired Mike Cerullo as Director of Football Administration. <ref name=Katzenstein2>{{cite news|url=http://www.nola.com/saints/index.ssf/2017/12/sean_payton_mike_cerullo.html|title=Sean Payton: NFL hiring of bounty whistleblower Mike Cerullo 'unbelievable'|last=Katzenstein|first=Josh|publisher=[[NOLA.com]]|date=2017-12-10}}</ref>
==Findings revealed== Late in the 2011 season, the NFL received what it called "significant and credible new information" that suggested there was indeed a "bounty" program in place.<ref name=NFLStatement/> League officials, convinced that this information was irrefutable evidence a program was indeed in place, alerted Benson of their findings just before the Saints' first-round playoff game against the [[Detroit Lions]].<ref name=KingOutofBounds>{{cite news|url=https://www.si.com/vault/issue/1009529/62/2|title=Way out of Bounds|last=King|first=Peter|authorlink=Peter King (sportswriter)|publisher=[[Sports Illustrated]]|date=2012-03-12}}</ref> The investigation continued during the [[2011–12 NFL playoffs|2011–12 playoffs]] and continued through the 2012 offseason.
On March 2, 2012, [[ESPN]]'s [[Adam Schefter]] reported that the NFL had indeed found evidence of a bounty program.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/video/clip?id=espn:7638694|title=Saints D Kept Bounty Fund|publisher=[[ESPN]]|date=2012-03-02}}</ref> Later that day, the NFL announced it had obtained irrefutable proof of a bounty pool dating back to the 2009 season, based on a review of 18,000 documents. It determined that Williams had initiated the fund soon after he arrived in New Orleans in 2009, in hopes of making the defense more aggressive. Between 22 and 27 Saints defensive players were involved. The players and Williams contributed their own cash to the pot, and received cash payments based on their performance in the previous week's game. For instance, a [[special teams|special teamer]] who downed a kick returner inside the receiving team's 20-yard-line earned $100. Players could also be fined for mental mistakes and penalties. Players also received "bounties" for "cart-offs" (plays in which an opponent was removed from the field on a stretcher or cart) and "knockouts" (plays that resulted in a player being unable to return for the rest of the game). Players usually earned $1,000 for "cart-offs" and $1,500 for "knockouts" during the regular season, though they were encouraged to put their winnings back into the pot in order to raise the stakes as the season went on. Payments were known to double or even triple during the playoffs.<ref name=NFLStatement/><ref name=KingOutofBounds/><ref name=NFLPenalties>{{cite web|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/09000d5d827c15b2/article/nfl-announces-management-discipline-in-saints-bounty-matter|title=NFL announces management discipline in Saints' 'bounty' matter|work=NFL.com}}</ref>
The NFL sent a confidential and detailed memo to all 32 teams detailing its findings. It revealed that the Saints had not only targeted Warner and Favre during the 2009 playoffs, but had also targeted [[Green Bay Packers]] quarterback [[Aaron Rodgers]] and [[Carolina Panthers]] quarterback [[Cam Newton]] during the 2011 regular season.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://espn.go.com/blog/nfcsouth/post/_/id/32684/nfl-saints-targeted-cam-newton|title=NFL: Saints targeted Cam Newton|last=Yasinskas|first=Pat|publisher=[[ESPN]]|date=2012-03-21}}</ref> According to that memo, Saints linebacker [[Jonathan Vilma]] offered $10,000 cash to any teammate who knocked Favre out of the NFC Championship Game.<ref name=King/> Another source told CBSSports.com's Mike Freeman that [[Reggie Bush]]'s agent at the time, Michael Ornstein, was closely involved in the scheme from the beginning. Ornstein contributed $10,000 to the pot in 2009, and an undisclosed amount in 2011.<ref name=Freeman1>{{cite news|url=http://mike-freeman.blogs.cbssports.com/mcc/blogs/entry/6264363/35066335|title=NFL memo details more Saints bounty accusations|last=Freeman|first=Mike|publisher=[[CBSSports.com]]|date=2012-03-02|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120306043855/http://mike-freeman.blogs.cbssports.com/mcc/blogs/entry/6264363/35066335|archivedate=2012-03-06|df=}}</ref>
After later investigations in the 2012 offseason, the NFL also found evidence that the Saints put a bounty on then-[[Seattle Seahawks]] quarterback, [[Matt Hasselbeck]] during their 2011 wild-card playoffs game.
The league found that Payton not only knew about the scheme, but tried to cover it up during both league investigations. During the 2010 investigation, Payton told Williams and Vitt to "make sure our ducks are in a row" when the league interviewed them. Before the start of the 2011 season, Payton received an email from Ornstein detailing the broader lines of the scheme. In that same email, Ornstein offered $5,000 to anyone who knocked Rodgers out of the 2011 season opener. Payton initially denied knowing that this email existed, but subsequently admitted that in fact he had read it.<ref name=KingOutofBounds/><ref name=Freeman1/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nola.com/saints/index.ssf/2012/03/mike_ornsteins_association_wit.html|title=Mike Ornstein's association with New Orleans Saints and bounty scandal a perplexing situation|last=Duncan|first=Jeff|publisher=[[The Times-Picayune]]|date=2012-03-09}}</ref><ref name=ESPNPenaltyAnnouncement>{{cite news|url=http://espn.go.com/nfl/story/_/id/7718136/sean-payton-new-orleans-saints-banned-one-year-bounties|title=NFL hammers Saints for bounties|publisher=[[ESPN]]|date=2012-03-21}}</ref>
When Benson was informed of the league's findings, he called in Payton and Loomis and ordered the program shut down immediately. However, they did not do so. Loomis had been interviewed during the 2010 investigation as well, and had stated that he knew of no such scheme and would stop it immediately if it was taking place. The league also found that Vitt, whom Payton had assigned to monitor Williams (the two reportedly didn't get along very well), also knew about the broader lines of the scheme and even witnessed Williams handing out payments to players. However, Vitt failed to tell anyone about it.<ref name=NFLStatement/><ref name=NFLPenalties/>
The NFL found that Payton and Loomis' [[misfeasance]] amounted to "conduct detrimental" to the league.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/09000d5d82757bcd/article/nfl-says-saints-created-bounty-program-from-20092011|title=NFL says Saints created 'bounty' program from 2009–2011|publisher=[[National Football League]]|date=2012-03-02}}</ref> The NFL found no club money had been used to fund the bounty pool, and praised Benson for doing what he could to shut down the slush fund. Nonetheless, it found the Saints organization as a whole guilty of conduct detrimental to the league as well due to Williams and the players' maintenance of the bounty pool, as well as Loomis and Payton's failure to act "in a responsible manner" to stop it.<ref name=NFLPenalties/><ref name=KingMarch5>{{cite news|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2012/writers/peter_king/03/05/offseason/index.html|title=As bounty fallout continues, Goodell to make example of Saints|last=King|first=Peter|authorlink=Peter King (sportswriter)|work=[[Sports Illustrated]]|date=2012-03-05}}</ref>
Several [[Chicago Bears]] players and fans believe that the Bears were targets of this program during the second game of the 2011 season, a 30–13 loss to the Saints. Quarterback [[Jay Cutler (American football)|Jay Cutler]] was sacked six times, and nearly lost his voice when a Saints player kicked him in the throat. Later in the game, offensive tackle [[Frank Omiyale]] yanked a Saints defender off Cutler when he saw what he later called "some dirty stuff."<ref>{{cite web|last=Wright |first=Michael C. |url=http://espn.go.com/blog/chicago/bears/post/_/id/4675326/bears-wonder-if-saints-targeted-them |title=Bears wonder if Saints targeted them |publisher=[[ESPN|ESPN Chicago]] |date= |accessdate=2012-03-06}}</ref> [[Tampa Bay Buccaneers]] quarterback [[Josh Freeman]] reported that the Saints' tendency toward illegal hits was common knowledge among the Tampa Bay coaching staff. Preparations for Saints games included warnings to offensive players to keep their knees protected, especially on plays near the sidelines.<ref>Stroud, Rick. "Josh Freeman says Tampa Bay Buccaneers were warned about New Orleans Saints' 'cheap shots'". ''[[Tampa Bay Times]]''. 6 Mar 2012. [http://www.tampabay.com/sports/football/bucs/josh-freeman-says-tampa-bay-buccaneers-were-warned-about-new-orleans/1218483]</ref>
In June 2012, the league revealed that it possessed a [[ledger]] detailing the weekly earnings of the players, which are earned for cart-offs ($1000) and "whacks" ($400) and deducted for "mental errors".<ref>{{cite web|author=Jason Cole|url=https://sports.yahoo.com/news/nfl--sources--new-orleans-saints-kept-a--ledger--detailing-weekly-earnings-in-bounty-scandal.html|title=Sources: New Orleans Saints kept a 'ledger' detailing weekly earnings in bounty scandal|publisher=Sports.yahoo.com|date=2012-06-27|accessdate=2012-08-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/09000d5d82982f9f/article/report-saints-ledger-shows-cartoffs-worth-1k?module=HP11_headline_stack|title=Report: Saints Ledger Shows Cart-offs Worth 1K|publisher=NFL.com|date=June 1, 2012|accessdate=2012-11-22}}</ref>
However, on July 26, 2012, Vilma and seven witnesses from the Saints testified in front of a federal judge in New Orleans that NFL commissioner Roger Goodell got his facts wrong in the bounty scandal."Everybody was sworn in under oath in front of a judge with the risk of perjury and jail time if we were lying, and categorically denied there was a bounty," Vilma said in a text message to ESPN's [[Ed Werder]]. "Seven people testified, 2 sworn affidavits (one by Drew Brees) all saying the same thing. I ask that you and ESPN report the facts. No more bias or b.s. or hearsay. I gave you facts that you can report if so choose."<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/nfl/story/_/id/8202975/new-orleans-saints-linebacker-jonathan-vilma-testifies|title=New Orleans Saints linebacker Jonathan Vilma testifies|work=ESPN.com}}</ref> Tulane University Sports Law Program Director Gabe Feldman (who attended the hearing in court) said, "Clearly the judge, by her questions, indicated she thinks Goodell overstepped his authority, and this case was always going to be about if he executed his power fairly... The NFL's retort is that with all due deference, you don't get to second guess (commissioner Roger Goodell). Judges only have limited jurisdiction over arbitration issues."<ref name="autogenerated2">{{cite web|url=http://www.nola.com/saints/index.ssf/2012/07/new_orleans_saints_linebacker_39.html|title=New Orleans Saints linebacker Jonathan Vilma does not receive restraining order, still hopeful for favorable ruling|work=NOLA.com}}</ref>
Saints All-Pro quarterback Drew Brees made a somewhat controversial tweet on June 20, 2012 stating, "If NFL fans were told there were "weapons of mass destruction" enough times, they'd believe it. But what happens when you don't find any????" Brees immediately issued another statement to clarify, "My WMD comment has nothing to do with politics or our brave military. Merely an analogy to show how media influences public perception." He went on to say, "I apologize if the WMD comment offended anyone. Especially our military. There is no one I respect more than our service men and women."<ref name="klopman1">{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/06/20/drew-brees-wmd-tweet-apologizes-saints-bounty_n_1613163.html|work=Huffington Post|first=Michael|last=Klopman|title=NFL Star Apologizes For Controversial 'WMD' Tweet|date=2012-06-20}}</ref>
==Other allegations against Williams== Shortly after the Saints' bounty system came to light, four former [[Washington Redskins]] players, as well as a coach, told ''[[The Washington Post]]'' that Williams operated a similar system while he was the Redskins' defensive coordinator from 2004 to 2007. The players said that Williams paid his crew thousands of dollars for aggressive play, with the biggest payouts—as much as $8,000—coming for "kill shots" that knocked opposing players out of games.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/sports/redskins/washington-redskins-offered-bounties-for-big-hits-under-former-assistant-coach-gregg-williams/2012/03/02/gIQAH0RlnR_story.html|title=Washington Redskins offered bounties for big hits under former assistant coach Gregg Williams|last=Maske|first=Mark|publisher=The Washington Post|date=2012-03-03}}</ref> ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'' NFL analyst [[Matt Bowen (American football)|Matt Bowen]], who played for the Redskins at the time, later wrote in one of his regular columns that the bounty pool was funded by fines for mistakes made during practice and in games, and insisted similar systems operated on other teams.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/sports/football/bears/ct-spt-0304-bowen-nfl--20120304,0,4015992.column|title=Bounties part of game across the NFL|last=Bowen|first=Matt|authorlink=Matt Bowen (American football)|publisher=Chicago Tribune|date=2012-03-03}}</ref> On March 4, ''The Post'' reported that the NFL was investigating the allegations against Williams with the Redskins.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/sports/redskins/nfl-to-investigate-redskins-over-bounty-allegations/2012/03/03/gIQAwS9XpR_story.html|title=NFL to investigate Redskins over bounty allegations under Gregg Williams|last=Maske|first=Mark|work=The Washington Post|date=2012-03-04}}</ref>
Several former Bills players subsequently told ''[[The Buffalo News]]'' of a similar system during Williams' tenure as Bills' head coach from 2001 to 2003. However, they didn't agree on whether there were rewards for intentionally injuring players. [[Coy Wire]], a safety during Williams' tenure, said that Williams gave bonuses for hits that left opponents seriously injured, and two other players said that bonuses were also awarded for "knockouts." However, linebacker [[Eddie Robinson (linebacker)|Eddie Robinson]], who played for Williams in Houston and Tennessee as well as in Buffalo, acknowledged an incentive pool but said he never heard Williams favor deliberately injuring other players.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.buffalonews.com/sports/bills-nfl/article747663.ece|title=Bills had bounty system under Gregg Williams, players say|last=Graham|first=Tim|publisher=[[The Buffalo News]]|date=2012-03-04}}</ref> [[Ruben Brown]], a guard for the Bills during Williams's time as coach there, denied there was any sort of bounty system in place in Buffalo,<ref>[http://www.wgrz.com/news/article/158807/37/Ruben-Brown-says-Bills-Didnt-Run-Bounty-System Ruben Brown says Bills didn't run bounty system] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120918070810/http://www.wgrz.com/news/article/158807/37/Ruben-Brown-says-Bills-Didnt-Run-Bounty-System |date=2012-09-18 }}. [[WGRZ]]. Retrieved March 4, 2012.</ref> a position reiterated by linebacker [[London Fletcher]] and then-general manager [[Tom Donahoe]].<ref>Pergament, Alan (March 7, 2012). [http://stilltalkintv.com/2012/03/the-voice-is-smashing-success-here/ The Voice is smashing success here] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120511182128/http://stilltalkintv.com/2012/03/the-voice-is-smashing-success-here/ |date=2012-05-11 }}. Retrieved March 7, 2012.</ref><ref>Gaughan, Mark (March 7, 2012). [http://www.buffalonews.com/sports/article750879.ece Donahoe disputes Bountygate]. ''The Buffalo News''. Retrieved March 7, 2012.</ref> [[Chidi Ahanotu]], who played one year under Williams in Buffalo, indicated that such a program was not within his character at the time and that Williams was "the softest coach I've been around."<ref>Hanzus, Dan (April 8, 2012). [http://www.nfl.com/news/story/09000d5d82829cad/article/retired-bills-de-gregg-williams-was-softest-coach?module=HP11_headline_stack Retired Bills DE: Gregg Williams was softest coach]. NFL.com. Retrieved April 8, 2012.</ref>
Former NFL coach [[Tony Dungy]] later told [[Profootballtalk.com]] he was certain that Williams operated a similar bounty system while he was defensive coordinator of the Oilers/Titans from 1997 to 2000. He also believes that Williams put a bounty on [[Indianapolis Colts]] quarterback [[Peyton Manning]] during Super Bowl XLIV, and targeted Manning on several occasions while with the Titans. The revelation of the bounty system also caused renewed speculation about a 2006 game between the Redskins and Colts, in which Manning was knocked down by a high-low hit from the Redskins' [[Phillip Daniels]] and [[Andre Carter]] and appeared to lose some feeling in his neck. While Dungy didn't speculate at the time about whether the Redskins targeted Manning on that play, he believes that hit ultimately caused the neck problems that sidelined Manning for the entire 2011 season and led to his departure for the [[Denver Broncos]] afterward.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://profootballtalk.nbcsports.com/2012/03/02/dungy-titans-had-a-bounty-on-peyton-manning|title=Dungy: Titans had a bounty on Peyton Manning|last=Florio|first=Mike|publisher=[[Profootballtalk.com]]/[[NBC Sports]]|date=2012-03-02}}</ref>
Former safety [[Ryan Clark (American football)|Ryan Clark]], who played under Williams in Washington from 2004–2005 and himself was fined by the NFL $40,000 for a helmet-to-helmet hit against [[Baltimore Ravens]] tight end [[Ed Dickson]] during the 2011 season,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/nfl/story/_/id/7212307/ryan-clark-pittsburgh-steelers-fined-40k-takes-jab-roger-goodell|title=Ryan Clark of Pittsburgh Steelers fined $40K, takes jab at Roger Goodell|publisher=Espn.go.com|date=2011-11-10|accessdate=2012-08-15}}</ref> defended Williams, saying that he never ran a bounty program with the Redskins and has yet to see one during his time in the NFL. Clark added that he would've reported Williams or any coach that offered to run such a program.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://profootballtalk.nbcsports.com/2012/03/05/ryan-clark-says-hes-not-aware-of-any-bounties-anywhere/|title=Ryan Clark says he's not aware of any bounties, anywhere | ProFootballTalk|publisher=Profootballtalk.nbcsports.com|date=March 15, 2012|accessdate=2012-08-15}}</ref> The Steelers released a statement on their official web site mentioning that the team does not condone any sort of bounty program.<ref>{{cite web|last=Varley|first=Teresa|url=http://www.steelers.com/news/article-1/Bounties-seen-as-player-safety-issue/688bcc61-73dd-4c2c-bd6d-797034ef26a0|title=Bounties seen as player safety issue|publisher=Steelers.com|date=2012-03-06|accessdate=2012-08-15}}</ref>
==Aftermath== Williams, who left after the season to become defensive coordinator of the [[St. Louis Rams]], was summoned to NFL headquarters after the investigation concluded in mid-February. He initially denied any involvement, but recanted and admitted everything in a meeting with Goodell.<ref name=KingOutofBounds/> After the story broke, Williams issued a statement calling his involvement "a terrible mistake." Williams said that he knew all along the slush fund broke the rules, and that "I should have stopped it" rather than get further involved.<ref name=ESPNBounty/> Goodell said in a statement that he found it "particularly disturbing" that the Saints were deliberately trying to injure other players. He said that players and coaches involved in the scheme could face fines or suspensions, and the Saints could be docked picks in the [[2012 NFL Draft]] and future drafts.<ref name=NFLStatement/><ref name=ESPNBounty/>
Benson issued a statement on the Saints' Website saying, "I have been made aware of the NFL’s findings relative to the “Bounty Rule” and how it relates to our club. I have offered and the NFL has received our full cooperation in their investigation. While the findings may be troubling, we look forward to putting this behind us and winning more championships in the future for our fans."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.neworleanssaints.com/news-and-events/article-1/Statement-From-Saints-Owner-Tom-Benson/76e57e46-fa7a-4594-b522-ae05a60b8a4b |title=Statement From Saints Owner Tom Benson |publisher=[[New Orleans Saints]]|date=2012-03-03}}</ref>
On March 3, [[Fox Sports (United States)|Fox Sports]]' [[Jay Glazer]] reported that the NFL intended to hand down penalties before the owners' meeting in late March.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://msn.foxsports.com/video/NFL?vid=60c358ee-8239-4b7e-993c-03d808b0e978|title=Goodell plans swift justice for Saints bounty hunters|last=Glazer|first=Jay|authorlink=Jay Glazer|publisher=[[Fox Sports (United States)|Fox Sports]]|date=2012-03-03}}</ref> The NFLPA asked the league to delay any sanctions until the union could conduct its own investigation.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://espn.go.com/nfl/story/_/id/7681965/nflpa-asks-nfl-delay-new-orleans-saints-punishment-allow-investigation|title=Union asks for Saints discipline delay|publisher=[[ESPN]]|date=2012-03-13}}</ref>
CBSSports.com's Pat Kirwan [[Twitter|tweeted]] that within hours of the NFL releasing its report, lawyers for several players were already telling him that their clients were considering legal action against the Saints and Williams.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.sbnation.com/nfl/2012/3/2/2840419/new-orleans-saints-bounty-program-lawsuits/in/2604084|title=Players Injured By New Orleans Saints Could Take Legal Action|last=McCauley|first=Kevin|publisher=[[SB Nation]]|date=2012-03-02}}</ref> Former [[San Francisco 49ers]] quarterback [[Steve Young]], who has a law degree from [[J. Reuben Clark Law School|BYU]], suggested that anyone who had been injured during a Saints game during the scheme's existence has grounds for a lawsuit.<ref name=Easterbrook>{{cite news|url=http://espn.go.com/espn/page2/story/_/id/7652028/saints-bounty-scandal-worse-spygate-example-sets-all-other-levels-football|title=Saints scandal threatens NFL integrity|last=Easterbrook|first=Gregg|authorlink=Gregg Easterbrook|publisher=[[ESPN]]|date=2012-03-06}}</ref> [[Paul M. Hebert Law Center|Louisiana State University]] law professor William Corbett told Fox Sports that any legal action by players has a chance of succeeding. He cited a 1977 case in which [[Denver Broncos]] defensive back [[Dale Hackbart]] sued the [[Cincinnati Bengals]] for a late hit to the back by running back [[Boobie Clark]] that fractured three vertebrae four years earlier and ended his career. A Colorado court ruled against Hackbart, saying violence was part of the game. However, the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit|10th Circuit Court of Appeals]] disagreed, saying that "the general customs of football" do not include deliberately attempting to injure opposing players.<ref name=FoxLegal>{{cite news|url=http://msn.foxsports.com/nfl/story/gregg-williams-new-orleans-saints-bounty-issue-may-have-legal-implications-for-nfl-030812|title=Bounty issue could be NFL legal problem|last=Perez|first=A. J.|publisher=[[Fox Sports (United States)|Fox Sports]]|date=2012-03-09}}</ref>
On March 6, Payton and Loomis issued a statement taking "full responsibility" for not stopping the alleged "bounty" program. Payton and Loomis also apologized to Benson and the Saints fans, and promised that such behavior would never happen again.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.neworleanssaints.com/news-and-events/article-1/Joint-Statement-from-Saints-Executive-VPGeneral-Manager-Mickey-Loomis--HC-Sean-Payton-/de51300a-8219-4508-8eae-2b060c2a45bb |title=Joint Statement from Saints Executive VP/General Manager Mickey Loomis & HC Sean Payton |publisher=[[New Orleans Saints]]|date=2012-03-06}}</ref> Three days later, [[Drew Brees]], the starting quarterback for the Saints, issued a statement denying any knowledge of or involvement in the program.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://sports.yahoo.com/blogs/nfl-shutdown-corner/brees-says-had-no-knowledge-saints-bounties-222603098.html|title=Brees says he had no knowledge of Saints’ bounties|last=Farrar|first=Doug|date=10 March 2012|publisher=Yahoo! Sports|accessdate=11 March 2012}}</ref> On March 12, [[WWL-TV]] in New Orleans reported that Payton and Benson met with Goodell in New York for much of the morning to reiterate that the Saints would continue to cooperate fully with the NFL's investigation.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.wwltv.com/sports/black-and-gold/Report-Saints-Payton-Benson-in-New-York-meeting-with-NFL-142348695.html|title=Saints' Payton, Owner Benson return from requested meeting with NFL commissioner|publisher=[[WWL-TV]]|date=2012-03-12|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120314163447/http://www.wwltv.com/sports/black-and-gold/Report-Saints-Payton-Benson-in-New-York-meeting-with-NFL-142348695.html|archivedate=2012-03-14|df=}}</ref> On March 22, [[United States Senate|U.S. Senator]] [[Dick Durbin|Richard Durbin]] of [[Illinois]] announced he would invite Goodell and the heads of the other major American sports leagues to a hearing on bounty systems. He also said that unless the leagues themselves "come up with standards to make sure this isn't going to happen again," he may consider drafting legislation that would extend federal sports bribery laws to cover bounties.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://espn.go.com/nfl/story/_/id/7722853/new-orleans-saints-senator-dick-durbin-sets-hearing-bounties-nfl|title=Senate to hold hearing on bounties|publisher=[[ESPN]]|date=2012-03-22}}</ref>
On April 5, documentary filmmaker [[Sean Pamphilon]] released audio of a meeting Williams held with his defense before their 2012 divisional playoff game against the [[San Francisco 49ers]]. In a profanity-laced speech, Williams instructed his players to deliberately try to injure several 49ers players. He ordered his men to try to knock out running back [[Kendall Hunter]], even if it meant hitting him out of bounds. He specifically directed them to try to [[Anterior cruciate ligament injury|tear]] wide receiver [[Michael Crabtree]]'s [[anterior cruciate ligament|ACL]], injure tight end [[Vernon Davis]]' ankles and go after kick returner [[Kyle Williams (wide receiver)|Kyle Williams]] specifically because he had a history of concussions. He also appeared to put a bounty on quarterback [[Alex Smith]]; according to Pamphilon, after Williams told his men to hit Smith in the chin, "then he rubs his thumb against his index and middle fingers – the cash sign – and says, ''I got the first one. I got the first one. Go get it. Go lay that motherfucker out.''" Pamphilon, who was doing a documentary on [[Steve Gleason]] and his fight against Lou Gehrig's Disease, released the audio to [[Yahoo! Sports]] without Gleason's approval.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://sports.yahoo.com/nfl/news;_ylt=Anw9sHdXItbteN7R4ozB1Qg5nYcB?slug=ms-silver_gregg_williams_speech_saints_49ers_bounty_040412|title=Source: Gregg Williams instructed Saints during speech to injure Niners offensive players|last=Silver|first=Michael|publisher=[[Yahoo! Sports]]|date=2012-04-05}}</ref><ref>{{YouTube|fhnn9kbqQUA|Audio of Williams' meeting with Saints defense}}</ref> However, the Saints were not penalized for illegal hits during that game, which they lost 36–32.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/football/nfl/gameflash/2012/01/14/4813/index.html#boxscore|work=CNN|title=Stingy 49ers hold down Drew Brees, Saints 36-32}}</ref>
==Sanctions== ===Coaches and front office staff=== On March 21, 2012, the NFL issued sanctions to Saints coaches and front-office personnel for their roles in the scandal.<ref name="sanction">{{cite web|title=NFL suspends Saints coach Payton for one year without pay|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/09000d5d827c0dd9/article/nfl-suspends-saints-coach-payton-for-one-year-without-pay?module=HP11_breaking_news|publisher=NFL.com}}</ref><ref name=USATodayPenalties>{{cite news|url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/thehuddle/post/2012/03/sean-peyton-suspended-saints-fined-for-bounty-program/1#.T2oL-RHS7i0|title=Sean Payton suspended, Saints fined for bounty program|work=USA Today|date=2012-03-21|accessdate=January 12, 2014}}</ref> * Williams was suspended indefinitely, and was banned from applying for reinstatement until the end of the 2012 season at the earliest. * Payton was suspended for the entire 2012 season, effective April 1. He is the first head coach in modern NFL history to be suspended for any reason. * Loomis was suspended for the first eight games of the 2012 season. * Vitt, who had been tabbed as a possible candidate to serve as interim coach in Payton's absence, was suspended for the first six games of the 2012 season.<ref name=NFLPenalties/><ref name=ESPNPenaltyAnnouncement/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://espn.go.com/blog/nfcsouth/post/_/id/32658/candidates-to-coach-the-saints|title=Candidates to coach the Saints|last=Yasinkas|first=Pat|publisher=[[ESPN]]|date=2012-03-21}}</ref> (This did not automatically disqualify Vitt from serving as interim head coach ''per se'', as his suspension was not effective until the regular season; the suspension terms allowed him to coach the team through training camp and the preseason, then return during Week 7. The Saints announced they would implement this scenario for 2012.)<ref>[http://content.usatoday.com/communities/thehuddle/post/2012/04/reports-bill-parcells-wont-coach-saints-in-2012/1#.T4Sfr7HJprZ Reports: Bill Parcells won't coach Saints in 2012]. ''USA Today''. Retrieved April 10, 2012.</ref><ref>[http://espn.go.com/nfl/story/_/id/7806938/joe-vitt-tabbed-coach-new-orleans-saints-sean-payton-absence Joe Vitt tabbed as coach of the New Orleans Saints in Sean Payton's absence]. ESPN.com. Retrieved April 13, 2012.</ref>
The Saints were also fined $500,000—the maximum fine permitted under the league constitution, and had to forfeit their second-round draft picks in 2012 and 2013 (their first-round pick in 2012 had already been traded to the [[New England Patriots]], and therefore, could not be forfeited; after the penalty; the Saints' first pick in the [[2012 NFL Draft]] is a third-rounder)<ref name=NFLPenalties/><ref name=ESPNPenaltyAnnouncement/> He also gave the league's clubs until March 30, 2012 to certify in writing that they do not have bounty programs. Clubs will also be required to certify that no bounty systems exist as part of the yearly certifications they must make under the league's Integrity of the Game Policy.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://nflcommunications.com/2012/03/21/all-clubs-directed-to-ensure-no-bounty-programs-exist|title=All clubs directed to ensure no bounty programs exist|publisher=[[National Football League]]|date=2012-03-21|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120324075858/http://nflcommunications.com/2012/03/21/all-clubs-directed-to-ensure-no-bounty-programs-exist/|archivedate=2012-03-24|df=}}</ref>
In a statement, Goodell said that the NFL would not tolerate "conduct or a culture" that put player safety at risk. He also said that the fact that the scheme went on for three years demanded that "a strong and lasting message must be sent that such conduct is totally unacceptable and has no place in the game."<ref name=NFLPenalties/> He was particularly upset that those involved had lied about the scheme on two separate investigations, and had denied that there was ever a bounty program in place. In an interview with [[NFL Network]]'s [[Rich Eisen]], Goodell said that the threat to player safety, as well as the fact the Saints lied about it, demanded significant punishment. "I don't think you can be too hard on people that put at risk our players' health and safety," Goodell told Eisen.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/09000d5d827c28ff/article/goodell-sounds-off-on-saints-bounty-penalties|title=Commissioner Goodell says NFL was misled in 'bounty' probe|publisher=[[National Football League]]|date=2012-03-21}}</ref> He reiterated this in an interview later that day with ESPN's Schefter, saying that the fact those involved "continued to mislead" the league about it was a significant factor in the sanctions. "You have to be accountable and responsible in the NFL," Goodell said. Goodell also implied that Payton would have faced significant punishment in any event, since his contractual obligation to supervise his assistants meant that he at least should have known about the scheme. He also said that there would be zero tolerance for payments for in-game performance in the future, saying that payments for good play eventually escalate to bounties for deliberately injuring players.<ref name=GoodellSchefter>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/video/clip?id=7719075|title=Goodell talks punishments|publisher=[[ESPN]]|date=2012-03-21}}</ref> Later, Schefter said on ESPN's [[SportsCenter]] that league officials felt Payton was at least as guilty as Williams, despite initial focus on Williams' role as the mastermind in the scheme.
On March 30, Payton, Vitt and Loomis appealed their suspensions, and the Saints also appealed the fine and loss of draft picks.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbssports.com/nfl/story/18164762/saints-payton-to-appeal-yearlong-suspension-on-friday|title=Saints, Payton, GM Loomis, assistant Vitt appealing bounty penalties|publisher=[[CBSSports.com]]|date=2012-03-30}}</ref> Payton, Vitt and Loomis met with Goodell on April 5. After that meeting, Vitt's lawyer, David Cornwell, said that Payton and Loomis met with Williams before the divisional playoff game and ordered him to shut down the bounty program immediately. Cornwell contended that Williams was a "rogue coach," and the recently released audio of his meeting with the defense only proved it.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/09000d5d8281b86a/article/attorney-for-saints-joe-vitt-says-gregg-williams-went-rogue|title=Attorney for Saints' Joe Vitt says Gregg Williams went 'rogue'|last=Wyche|first=Steve|publisher=NFL.com|date=2012-04-05}}</ref>
Goodell denied the appeals on April 9, meaning that Payton's suspension began as of April 16. However, depending on the Saints' cooperation and that of the individuals involved, Goodell could restore the Saints' second-round pick in 2013 (though the Saints would still lose a lower-round pick), as well as reduce the fine on the Saints and restore Payton, Vitt and Loomis' lost pay. However, all appeals were denied<ref>{{cite news|url=http://espn.go.com/nfl/story/_/id/7792405/nfl-upholds-suspension-new-orleans-saints-sean-payton-mickey-loomis-joe-vitt|title=NFL denies Saints' appeals|publisher=[[ESPN]]|date=2012-04-09}}</ref>
===Players=== The NFLPA requested that the league should hold off on any punishments for the players until it conducts its own investigation.<ref name=ESPNPenaltyAnnouncement/> Goodell told Schefter, however, that he would hand down punishments to the players involved very soon once he gets feedback from the NFLPA.<ref name=GoodellSchefter/>
Hours after the sanctions were announced, Kluwe went on [[KSTP (AM)|KSTP]] in the Twin Cities and demanded that any players involved in the scheme be severely punished, and that the NFLPA let it be known that "there's no place in the league for that kind of behavior." He even went as far as to call for Vilma—the only player specifically named as being involved in the scheme in the NFL's initial announcements—to be banned from the league for life.<ref name=Zulgad>{{cite news|url=http://www.1500espn.com/sportswire/Zulgad_Chris_Kluwe_thinks_Jonathan_Vilma_should_be_banned_from_NFL032212|title=Chris Kluwe thinks Jonathan Vilma should be banned from NFL|last=Zulgad|first=Judd|publisher=[[KSTP (AM)]]|date=2012-03-22|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120324203456/http://www.1500espn.com/sportswire/Zulgad_Chris_Kluwe_thinks_Jonathan_Vilma_should_be_banned_from_NFL032212|archivedate=2012-03-24|df=}}</ref> His sentiments were echoed a day later by Vikings center [[John Sullivan (American football)|John Sullivan]], who told [[KFXN-FM]] in the Twin Cities that any Saint who deliberately tried to hurt Favre in that game should get a lifetime ban. Sullivan called the Saints' treatment of Favre "despicable" and "the exact opposite of sportsmanship," and even called for the league to take some sort of action against players involved in that game who had since retired, such as McCray.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://espn.go.com/blog/nfcnorth/post/_/id/39950/john-sullivan-saints-were-despicable|title=John Sullivan: Saints were "despicable"|last=Seifert|first=Kevin|publisher=[[ESPN]]|date=2012-03-23}}</ref>
On May 2, 2012, the NFL suspended four then-current or former Saints players for their involvement in the bounty scandal: * Vilma was suspended for the entire [[2012 NFL season]].<ref name="ESPNplayers" /> * Former Saints defensive tackle [[Anthony Hargrove]] was suspended for eight games. * Saints defensive end [[Will Smith (American football)|Will Smith]] was suspended for four games. * Former Saints linebacker [[Scott Fujita]] (then with the [[Cleveland Browns]], now retired) was suspended for three games.
Vilma's suspension took effect immediately, while the other three players are allowed to attend training camp. In announcing the suspensions, Goodell said that while a large number of players took part in the program, he chose to suspend those players who "were in leadership positions at the Saints; contributed a particularly large sum of money toward the program; specifically contributed to a bounty on an opposing player; demonstrated a clear intent to participate in a program that potentially injured opposing players; sought rewards for doing so; and/or obstructed the 2010 investigation." The NFL determined that Vilma and Smith helped Williams start the bounty program. Hargrove lied to league officials during the 2010 investigation, but later signed a letter to the NFL admitting that he was active participant in the scheme. He also told at least one other player that the Saints had put a bounty on Favre in the 2009 NFC title game. Fujita, who left the team for the Browns immediately after the Saints won [[Super Bowl XLIV]], pledged "a significant amount of money" into the bounty program.<ref name=NFLPlayerPenalties>[http://nfllabor.files.wordpress.com/2012/05/5-2-12-saints-players1.pdf NFL announcement of player sanctions]</ref>
Earlier, Goodell had indicated that he was going to come down hard on the players involved, telling Eisen that they "enthusiastically embraced" the scheme. "They are on the field, so so I don't think they are absolved from any responsibility because of that," he said.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/09000d5d8288d646/article/goodell-new-orleans-saints-players-embraced-bounties|title=Goodell: New Orleans Saints players 'embraced' bounties|last=Hanzus|first=Dan|publisher=[[National Football League]]|date=2012-04-24}}</ref>
The NFLPA released a statement calling the suspensions unjustified, claiming that Goodell had not furnished them with any evidence supporting the sanctions.<ref name="ESPNplayers" /> The union lodged a formal grievance on May 4, contending that since the suspensions were for on-field misconduct, the players' appeals should be heard by [[Ted Cottrell]] and [[Art Shell]], whom the collective bargaining agreement designates as the hearing officers for on-field sanctions. It also contended that since the alleged conduct took place before the most recent CBA was signed in August, Goodell should have deferred to NFL [[special master]] [[Stephen B. Burbank|Stephen Burbank]] in ruling on the players' actions.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbssports.com/nfl/story/18964180/union-bounty-grievance-goodell-has-no-authority-to-punish-hear-appeals|title=Union bounty grievance: Goodell has no authority to punish, hear appeals|publisher=[[CBSSports.com]]|date=2012-05-04}}</ref> Goodell issued the suspensions as part of his power to sanction any "conduct detrimental to the integrity and public confidence in the NFL," a violation of Article 46 of the CBA. This provision is normally used to sanction off-field conduct.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nola.com/saints/index.ssf/2012/05/new_orleans_saints_suspended_p.html|title=New Orleans Saints suspended players' appeals face uphill battle: expert|last=Varney|first=James|work=[[The Times-Picayune]]|date=2012-05-02}}</ref> However, a league source told CBSSports.com's Judge that it also gives Goodell the power to rule on in-game conduct if he feels that it runs counter to the integrity of the game.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbssports.com/nfl/story/18964610/legal-expert-union-may-be-fighting-losing-battle-in-bounty-grievances|title=Legal expert: Union may be fighting losing battle in bounty grievances|last=Judge|first=Clark|publisher=[[CBSSports.com]]|date=2012-05-04}}</ref>
On July 26, 2012, [[Jonathan Vilma]] and seven witnesses from the Saints testified in front of a federal judge in New Orleans that Goodell got his facts wrong in the bounty scandal. "Everybody was sworn in under oath in front of a judge with the risk of perjury and jail time if we were lying, and categorically denied there was a bounty," Vilma said in a text message to ESPN's Ed Werder. "Seven people testified, 2 sworn affidavits (one by Drew Brees) all saying the same thing. I ask that you and ESPN report the facts. No more bias or b.s. or hearsay. I gave you facts that you can report if so choose."<ref name="autogenerated1"/> Tulane University Sports Law Program Director Gabe Feldman (who attended the hearing in court) said, "Clearly the judge, by her questions, indicated she thinks Goodell overstepped his authority, and this case was always going to be about if he executed his power fairly... The NFL's retort is that with all due deference, you don't get to second guess (commissioner Roger Goodell). Judges only have limited jurisdiction over arbitration issues."<ref name="autogenerated2"/>
All four players appealed their suspensions. On September 7, 2012, the Burbank appeals panel vacated the suspensions imposed on the four, and the NFL confirmed that the ruling reinstated them in time for their first games of the 2012 season two days later.<ref>{{cite news|last=Chase|first=Chris|url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/thehuddle/post/2012/09/saints-players-have-suspensions-lifted-are-available-for-season-opener/1#.UEpk6rKPUl8|title=Saints bounty players have suspensions lifted, are available for season opener|work=USA Today|accessdate=7 September 2012|date=2012-09-07}}</ref> Two days after the fifth game of the season, on October 9, 2012, the league re-issued the suspensions without any changes or reductions; the players' appeals continued.<ref>{{cite news|last=Brooks|first=Matt|title=Report: NFL re-issues bounty suspensions for Saints players|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/early-lead/wp/2012/10/09/nfl-re-issues-bounty-suspensions-for-saints-players/|work=The Washington Times|accessdate=9 October 2012}}</ref>
On October 27, 2012, former league commissioner [[Paul Tagliabue]] postponed the bounty appeals hearing,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap1000000085951/article/nfl-postpones-new-orleans-saints-bounty-appeals-hearing|title=NFL postpones New Orleans Saints bounty appeals hearing|publisher=NFL|accessdate=October 27, 2012}}</ref> expecting to set a new schedule on October 29, 2012.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap1000000085952/article/paul-tagliabue-postpones-bounty-appeals-hearing|title=Paul Tagliabue postpones bounty appeals hearing|publisher=NFL|accessdate=October 27, 2012}}</ref> On December 11, with three games left in the regular season, Tagliabue vacated the players' suspensions, saying in his ruling, "I affirm Commissioner Goodell's factual findings as to the four players. I conclude that Hargrove, Smith and Vilma—but not Fujita—engaged in 'conduct detrimental to the integrity of, and public confidence in, the game of professional football ..." He laid primary responsibility for the scandal on Williams and Payton.<ref name=Tagliabuevacate>[http://espn.go.com/nfl/story/_/id/8736662/paul-tagliabue-vacates-new-orleans-players-bounty-penalties Paul Tagliabue vacates penalties]. [[ESPN]], 2012-12-11.</ref>
Had the suspensions of Vilma and Hargrove been upheld, they would have been the longest for an on-field incident in modern NFL history, topping the previous record set in [[2006 NFL season|2006]], when then-Titans defensive end [[Albert Haynesworth]] was given a five-game suspension for stomping on the head of [[Dallas Cowboys]] offensive lineman [[Andre Gurode]].
Vilma played the final 11 games of the 2012 season for the Saints; Smith played all 16. Fujita played the first four games of the season for the Browns before suffering a season-ending (and ultimately, career-ending) neck injury;<ref>{{cite web|url=https://sports.yahoo.com/news/season-over-browns-lb-scott-163452126--nfl.html|title=Season, maybe career, over for Browns' Fujita|publisher=[[Yahoo! Sports]]|date=2012-10-24|accessdate=2012-10-24}}</ref> he would sign a ceremonial one-day contract with the Saints in the offseason and retire with the team.<ref>Jeff Duncan, [http://www.nola.com/saints/index.ssf/2013/04/scott_fujita_retires_from_nfl.html "Scott Fujita retires from NFL as a New Orleans Saint"], ''[[Times-Picayune]]'', April 22, 2013.</ref> Hargrove, signed as a free agent by the [[Green Bay Packers]] in March 2012,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://espn.go.com/nfl/story/_/id/7751195/2012-nfl-free-agency-green-bay-packers-get-defensive-lineman-anthony-hargrove|title=Packers Get Anthony Hargrove|publisher=ESPN|date=March 29, 2012|accessdate=February 4, 2013}}</ref> did not play during the 2012 season. Nonetheless, the loss of Payton, combined with the distractions caused by the scandal, proved too much for the Saints to overcome. After finishing 13–3 and reaching the Divisional round of the playoffs a year earlier, they finished 7–9 and missed the playoffs.
==Media reaction== The behavior detailed in the report was almost universally condemned in the press. In an editorial, New Orleans' local paper ''[[The Times-Picayune]]'' called the revelations "an embarrassment for one of the most successful and beloved sports organizations of recent years," and that they were "particularly hard to take for (Saints') fans" in light of the Saints' rebound after [[Hurricane Katrina]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nola.com/opinions/index.ssf/2012/03/bounty_program_scandal_is_a_bl.html|title=Saints 'bounty program' is a black eye for a beloved franchise|work=[[The Times-Picayune]]|date=2012-03-03}}</ref> ESPN columnist [[Gregg Easterbrook]] claimed that the Saints' behavior threatened the very integrity of the sport since high school and youth players have long emulated what they see in the NFL. He also claimed that NFL Network yanked its planned replay of the 2009 NFC Championship Game due to concern that fans might look more closely for late hits that should have been called.<ref name=Easterbrook />
Most of the players who were the targets of questionable hits by the Saints, including Favre and Warner, claimed the bounties were merely part of the game.<ref name="FoxLegal" /> However, several former players interviewed by ''[[Sports Illustrated]]'' said that while payments for good hits and sacks were indeed considered part of the game, bounties for intentionally injuring opponents violated an unwritten code. One of those interviewed, [[Junior Seau]], bluntly said that such practices crossed the line into threatening a person's livelihood.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1195696/index.htm|title=The Conscience Of The Locker Room|last=Trotter|first=Jim|work=[[Sports Illustrated]]|date=2012-03-12}}</ref> (Seau would commit [[suicide]] less than two months after the interview was published; it was discovered after his death that he suffered from [[chronic traumatic encephalopathy]] (CTE) as a result of the numerous head injuries Seau suffered during his 20-year NFL career.)<ref>{{cite news |url=http://espn.go.com/espn/otl/story/_/id/8830344/study-junior-seau-brain-shows-chronic-brain-damage-found-other-nfl-football-players|title=Study: Junior Seau's brain shows chronic brain damage found in other NFL football players|publisher=ESPN.com|date=January 11, 2013 }}</ref> Seau's sentiments were echoed by Hall of Fame quarterback [[Fran Tarkenton]]. In an op-ed for ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'', Tarkenton wrote that he played against the likes of [[Mean Joe Greene]], [[Ray Nitschke]] and [[Dick Butkus]], and none of them even considered deliberately trying to hurt him. He also said that he discussed the issue with several players from his era, and they unanimously agreed that players who put bounties on opponents were "cowards."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052970203370604577265522200050922|title=Football's Bounty Hunters Must Be Clipped|last=Tarkenton|first=Fran|authorlink=Fran Tarkenton|work=The Wall Street Journal|date=2012-03-08}}</ref>
Kevin Seifert, who blogs on the [[NFC North]] for ESPN.com, wrote that neither he nor most Vikings fans were surprised at the discovery of the bounty program. Seifert argued that even before the findings were revealed, it was obvious that the Saints were determined to inflict a severe beating on Favre, even if it meant breaking the rules. The only difference in Seifert's mind was that he no longer believed the Saints were out of control. Rather, he wrote, they were acting as "part of a larger mentality" instilled by Williams.<ref name=Seifert/>
Speculation quickly abounded about how severely Goodell, who has made player safety and the overall integrity of the game a point of emphasis during his six years as commissioner, would punish Williams and the Saints. In his weekly "Monday Morning Quarterback" column on March 5, ''SI''{{'}}s [[Peter King (sportswriter)|Peter King]] wrote that he believed Williams faced at least an eight-game suspension, and that Payton and Loomis would almost certainly be suspended as well. He also argued that Goodell would have no choice but to come down hard on the Saints, given that the league was facing numerous lawsuits brought by former players who suffered head injuries. Given the circumstances, King said, Goodell had a lot of incentive to "issue a string of suspensions the likes of which the league has never seen."<ref name=KingMarch5/> In an article written for the March 12 edition of ''SI'', King wrote that league officials were so outraged that they were likely to hand down penalties similar to the season-long bans [[Paul Hornung]] and [[Alex Karras]] received in 1963 for gambling.<ref name=KingOutofBounds/> Freeman wrote that his sources in the league office had told him that the players, Williams, Payton and Loomis would all face suspensions of at least six games, as well as heavy fines. Freeman's sources also said that Payton's sanctions were likely to dwarf those handed down to the [[New England Patriots]]' [[Bill Belichick]] in the wake of the [[2007 National Football League videotaping controversy|2007 "Spygate"]] affair. He also believed that Goodell was going to use the scandal to "end the practice of bounty football forever," much like the penalties imposed against the Patriots after "Spygate" effectively ended the longstanding practice of illicit videotaping.<ref name=Freeman2/>
After the sanctions were announced, CBSSports.com's [[Gregg Doyel]] wrote that the severity of the punishments handed down to Williams, Payton and Loomis proved that Goodell was truly sincere in his desire to "take the thuggishness out of the NFL." Doyel also said that while many players had chafed at what they saw as Goodell's heavy-handed approach to discipline, he was actually standing up for their safety in the Saints' case.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbssports.com/nfl/story/17950395/long-seen-as-their-enemy-goodell-comes-down-decisively-for-players|title=Long seen as their enemy, Goodell comes down decisively for players|last=Doyel|first=Gregg|authorlink=Gregg Doyel|publisher=[[CBSSports.com]]|date=2012-03-21}}</ref> Pereira, now an analyst for Fox Sports, wrote that based on his experience in the league office, he wasn't surprised that Goodell came down hard on the Saints. He recalled that Goodell was always upset when officials didn't penalize hits on defenseless players.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://msn.foxsports.com/nfl/story/Roger-Goodell-New-Orleans-Saints-Bountygate-proves-commitment-to-player-safety-032212|title=Goodell shows commitment to player safety|last=Pereira|first=Mike|authorlink=Mike Pereira|publisher=[[Fox Sports (United States)|Fox Sports]]|date=2012-03-23}}</ref>
The revelation of Williams' pregame speech was also greeted with revulsion. ESPN NFL analyst and former [[Dallas Cowboys]] safety [[Darren Woodson]] said that much of Williams' speech was standard pregame rhetoric. According to Woodson, when Williams called for his men to "attack the head" of running back [[Frank Gore]], he was saying that the 49ers' offense would be rendered ineffective if they managed to shut Gore down. However, Woodson felt that several parts of Williams' speech—particularly his calls to go after Crabtree's ACL and target Williams specifically because he had concussions in the past—went too far.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://espn.go.com/video/clip?id=espn:7778213|title=Williams Crossed the Line|publisher=[[ESPN]]|date=2012-04-05}}</ref> His former teammate, NFL Network analyst [[Michael Irvin]], said that he "almost threw up" when he heard Williams tell his men to go after Crabtree's ACL, saying that players are taught from youth football onward to "never take out a man's knees."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nfl.com/videos/new-orleans-saints/09000d5d8281da6d/Michael-Irvin-s-thoughts-on-Saints-bounties|title=Michael Irvin's thoughts on Saints' bounties|publisher=[[NFL Network]]|date=2012-04-05}}</ref> Fox Sports' Mark Kriegel argued that the tape proved Williams was "woefully underpunished," especially since he made the speech after being alerted that the NFL had reopened its investigation. He called for Goodell to ban him from the league for life.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://msn.foxsports.com/nfl/story/Gregg-Williams-New-Orleans-Saints-Bountygate-must-be-banned-for-life-040512|title=Ban Williams from NFL for good|last=Kriegel|first=Mark|publisher=[[Fox Sports (United States)|Fox Sports]]|date=2012-04-06}}</ref>
NFL Network analyst [[Michael Lombardi (sportscaster)|Michael Lombardi]] wrote that the scandal happened in part because during Williams' previous stops as a defensive coordinator, the head coaches under which he worked—Fisher, [[Joe Gibbs]] and Payton—essentially ceded him complete authority over the defense. Lombardi claimed that as a result, Williams operated essentially as "an independent contractor." Lombardi argued that such a situation is "never fully sustainable," as it can easily lead to the head coach losing control.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/09000d5d82821ba1/article/williams-independentcontractor-status-fueled-rogue-mentality|title=Williams' independent-contractor status fueled rogue mentality|last=Lombardi|first=Michael|authorlink=Michael Lombardi (sportscaster)|publisher=[[NFL.com]]|date=2012-04-06}}</ref>
Despite the media outcry, an independent study speculated that Saints' players may have pretended to participate off the field but not put the tactics into action on the field. "If the Saints tended to injure more players, then teams that played them would tend to list more injuries the following week. To test whether the Saints injured more players than a typical team, one need only compare the number of players added to injury reports after a Saints game to the league-wide average. Did the New Orleans Saints injure more players? The data-driven answer is a resounding 'no.' The Saints appear to have injured far fewer players over the 2009, 2010 and 2011 seasons. The numbers are striking."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.aei.org/article/economics/the-saints-aint-sinners/|title=The Saints ain't sinners|last1=Hassett|first1=Kevin|authorlink=Kevin Hassett|last2=Veuger|first2=Stan|work=Los Angeles Times|date=2012-07-15}}</ref>

{{Expand German|topic=culture|date=March 2009|Niele Toroni}} [[File:Niele Toroni (1995).png|right|300px]] '''Niele Toroni''' (born March 15, 1937 in [[Muralto]]<ref>[http://www.swissinstitute.net/exhibition/niele-toroni/ Niele Toroni Jun 03 - Sep 06 2015] [[Swiss Institute Contemporary Art New York]]</ref>) is a [[Switzerland|Swiss]] [[Painting|painter]]. He lives and works in Paris.
==Work== In 1966 Toroni started a practice he calls "Travail-Peinture".<ref>[http://www.galeriegretameert.com/exhibitions/detail/107 Niele Toroni, March 27 - May 2, 2009] Galerie Greta Meert, Brussels.</ref> Toroni's method, brushstrokes made with imprints of a no. 50 paintbrush repeated at perpendicular 30 centimeter intervals,<ref>[http://www.renaissancesociety.org/site/Exhibitions/Intro.62.0.0.0.0.html Niele Toroni, September 23 – November 04, 1990] The Renaissance Society, Chicago.</ref> was first shown at a debut in 1967 in Paris at an exhibition-performance at the Salon de la Jeune Peinture in the Musèe d'Art Moderne de la Ville de Paris.<ref>[http://www.mariangoodman.com/exhibitions/2003-09-10_niele-toroni/ Niele Toroni, September 10 - October 11, 2003] Marian Goodman Gallery, New York.</ref> That same year, Toroni founded the [[BMPT (art group)]] together with [[Daniel Buren]], [[Olivier Mosset]], and Michel Parmentier.<ref>[http://www.capc-bordeaux.fr/en/niele-toroni Niele Toroni, ''Imprints of a No. 50 Paintbrush Repeated at Regular Intervals of 30 cm.''] CAPC Musée d'art contemporain de Bordeaux.</ref> In works like ''Miroir d’Eau'' (1973) and ''Vert Wagon'' (1977), the imprints made with a n°50 paintbrush are repeated at regular intervals of 30 cm.<ref>[http://www.mariangoodman.com/exhibitions/2012-02-24_tacita-dean-william-kentridge-gabriel-orozco-giuseppe-penone-niele-toroni-lawrence-weiner/ Tacita Dean, William Kentridge, Gabriel Orozco, Giuseppe Penone, Niele Toroni, Lawrence Weiner. February 24 - March 31, 2012] [[Marian Goodman Gallery]], Paris.</ref>
==Exhibitions== Toroni was included in [[documenta]]s 7 (1982) and 9 (1992); [[São Paulo Art Biennial]] in 1991; and the [[Venice Biennale]] of 1976. Solo exhibitions include shows at Museum Kurhaus Kleve, Kleve, Germany in 2002; Niele Toroni: Histoires de Peinture at l'ARC/[[Musée d'Art Moderne de la Ville de Paris]], in 2001; Musée Dhondt-Dhaenens, Deurle, and Avignon 2000, France in 2000. Other venues include: Base at Centro d'Arte, Florence and Niele Toroni, Siena Centro d'Arte Contemporani, Palazzo della Papesse, Siena in 1999; [[CAPC Musée d'Art Contemporain de Bordeaux]] in 1997; [[Gemeentemuseum Den Haag]], and [[Stedelijk Museum]], Amsterdam in 1994; [[Centre Georges Pompidou]] in 1991, and [[Musée d'Art Moderne de la Ville de Paris]] in 1990; [[Villa Arson]], Nice and the [[Musée de Grenoble]] in 1987. In 1995 he completed a Public Art Project on [[Rochdale Canal]], Manchester, England.<ref>[http://www.mariangoodman.com/exhibitions/2003-09-10_niele-toroni/ Niele Toroni, September 10 - October 11, 2003] Marian Goodman Gallery, New York.</ref>
Toroni is represented by [[Yvon Lambert Gallery]], Paris.
==Collections== Toroni's works are part of major collections, including the [[Museum of Modern Art]], New York; the [[Strasbourg Museum of Modern and Contemporary Art]], Strasbourg; the [[Kupferstichkabinett Berlin|Kupferstichkabinett]], Berlin; the Kunstmuseum Luzern; Migros Museum für Gegenwartskunst, Zürich.
==Recognition== Toroni received the [[Museum Ludwig|Wolfgang Hahn Prize]], [[Cologne]], Germany in 2003 and the French Vermeil Medal, awarded by the City of Paris in 2001.
